6. Define the design and stochastic spaces¶

In this section, the characterization of the model parameters and design variables is described. This characterization is performed through two files: design_space and stochastic_space. In design_space, the deterministic values for the model parameters and the range for the design variables are provided. In stochastic_space, uncertainty is allocated to the specific model parameters and design variables. When a deterministic optimization is performed, only the design_space file is required. In the other cases, i.e. uncertainty quantification and robust optimization, both files are required.

6.1. design_space¶

In this file, you define the model parameters which need a quantification in your model. When performing uncertainty quantification, the design_space file consists only of model parameters. In the case of deterministic optimization or robust optimization, the design_space file requires design variables. Additionally, if some model parameters require a quantification outside the model, the design_space file includes both design variables and model parameters. The file uses whitespace as delimiter between the inputs related to the parameters and variables.

6.1.1. design variables¶

The design variables are variables that are controllable by the designer within a certain range. This range should be provided, to shape the search space for the optimizer. To define a design variable, the set-up in the design_space file is as follows:

name parameter_type lb ub

where:

  • name: name of the variable;

  • parameter_type: a variable is indicated with var;

  • lb: lower bound value for the design variable;

  • ub: upper bound value for the design variable.

An example for a configured design variable n_pv with a range between 1e-8 and 50 is:

n_pv var 1e-8 50

6.1.2. model parameters¶

A model parameter corresponds to a parameter that usually cannot be controlled by the designer (EX GRAV CONSTANT), or the decision on this parameter value is fixed(EX N PV PANELS ON ROOF FIXED). Such a parameter can be considered deterministic or uncertain. In this file design_space, the deterministic value (or mean value when the parameter is considered uncertain) is provided. The configuration of a model parameter is similar to the configuration of a design variable:

name parameter_type mean

where:

  • name: name of the variable;

  • parameter_type: a parameter is indicated with par;

  • mean: mean value (or deterministic value if parameter is deterministic).

An example of a configured model parameter opex_dcdc with a mean value of 0.03 is:

opex_dcdc par 0.03

6.1.3. Example of design_space¶

Conclusively, an example of a configured design_space file, which consists of 3 model parameters (par_1, par_2 and par_3) and 2 design variables (design_var_1 and design_var_2), is presented:

par_1        par 4
par_2        par 2.5
par_3        par 175
design_var_1 var 1 3
design_var_2 var 1e-8 100

6.2. stochastic_space¶

This file is required when performing robust optimization and uncertainty quantification, where several parameters are subjected to uncertainty. This uncertainty can be allocated through the file stochastic_space. For every design variable and model parameter defined in design_space, an uncertainty can be defined. Defining the uncertainty of a parameter can be done through the following syntax:

name abs_rel distribution deviation

where:

  • name: name of the parameter or variable, equal to the name of the parameter or variable in design_space;

  • abs_rel: absolute or relative uncertainty to the mean, defined with absolute or relative, respectively;

  • distribution: The distribution of the uncertainty;

  • deviation: uncertainty on the mean.

A more detailed description of these parameters is available in Uncertainty characterization

An example of a configured uncertain parameter par_2, characterized by a Uniform distribution with a \(\pm 1\) deviation from the mean value:

par_2 absolute Uniform 1

Note that it is not required to allocate an uncertainty to every design variable and model parameter defined in design_space. In other words, when a parameter (or variable) is defined in design_space, but not in stochastic_space, the parameter (or variable) is considered deterministic. Moreover, the order of appearance of parameters and variables in design_space should not be kept in stochastic_space.

6.2.1. Uncertainty characterization¶

The following distributions are available:

  • Uniform

  • Gaussian

The meaning of deviation at the end of the line depends on the distribution. When a Uniform distribution is considered, the deviation refers to the absolute (or relative) difference between the upper bound of the Uniform distribution and the mean: for \(\mathcal{U}(a,b)\), \(deviation = (b-a)/2\)). When a Gaussian distribution is considered, the value corresponds to the standard deviation: \(\mathcal{N}(mean,deviation)\).

6.2.2. Example of stochastic_space¶

In summary, a stochastic_space file corresponding to the illustrative design_space example file in Example of design_space might look like this:

par_1        relative Gaussian 0.5
par_2        absolute Uniform  1
design_var_2 relative Uniform  0.1

Where the model parameter par_3 and design variable design_var_1 are considered deterministic, par_1 is characterized by a Gaussian distribution with a relative standard deviation of 0.5 (i.e. \(\mathcal{N}(4,2)\)), par_2 is characterized by a Uniform distribution with an absolute deviation of 1 (i.e. \(\mathcal{U}(1.5,3.5)\)) and design_var_2 is characterized by a Uniform distribution with a relative deviation of 0.1. For design_var_2, the actual Uniform distribution depends on the mean value selected by the optimizer for each evaluated design.
